nodes.text: The A95 Stingbeam was a small, concealable blaster produced by Czerka Arms. The weapon was shaped like a sabacc card with a long thin needle from which the blaster bolts were discharged. Stingbeams were used at formal events by assassins during the height of the Clone Wars.

The A95 Stingbeam was a small, lightweight blaster shaped like a sabacc card. It was exotic and easy to conceal, but had an effective range of only around an arm's length. Rather than using a Galven-pattern barrel like most blasters, blaster energy was channeled along and discharged from a long thin needle that protruded from between the user's fingers. The weapon possessed a stun setting.

Czerka Arms designed and produced the A95 Stingbeam, which cost 400 credits and competed in the niche microblaster market. Its re-imagined design differentiated it from microblasters, which generally conformed to the basic idea of a blaster.

Assassins made use of A95 Stingbeams during the height of the Clone Wars, using them to target Galactic Republic or Confederacy of Independent Systems senators at formal events. The weapon was also popular with grifters and con artists, as well as private security personnel, the latter of whom prefered the reduced risk of collateral damage caused by the Stingbeam's short range.

The A95 Stingbeam was mentioned in the new Star Wars canon in Gadgets and Gear, a 2019 role-playing supplement released by Fantasy Flight Games. The weapon originated in the Star Wars Legends continuity, where it was mentioned in the 2015 role-playing supplement Fly Casual.
